all_paragraphs: According to the Unruh effect, described by the physicists Stephen Fulling, Paul Davies, and W. G. Unruh, the vacuum for an accelerating observer will appear to have a temperature. In other words, if an observer is in an accelerated reference frame, he will detect particles, whereas, in a non-accelerated frame, he will not.
This article will closely follow the book by Mukhanov and Winitzki.

Until now, the analysis was classical and did not involve quantum mechanics. We will now quantize the theory.

The “correct” vacuum depends on the experiment being performed. For example, from the perspective of the accelerated (or Rindler) observer, the Minkowski vacuum is a state containing particles. In other words, if the quantum fields are in the Minkowski vacuum state, the detector of the Rindler observer will register the presence of massless particles. In contrast, if the quantum fields are in the Rindler vacuum it will not.
The transformations between the operators in Eq. 22 are called Bogolyubov transformations, named after the Soviet mathematician and theoretical physicist Nikolay Bogolyubov.

One can interpret the Unruh effect as follows. The fluctuations of the quantum vacuum interact with the detector carried by the accelerated observer. This interaction excites the detector as if it was in a thermal bath with the temperature given by Eq. 27. Note that the energy of such fluctuations is produced by whatever mechanism that generates the acceleration, such as, for example, a propulsion engine that accelerates the spaceship carrying the accelerated observer.
